Right, and the gliding team also showed that the femur needed more of a sprawling posture, not an upright posture like a chicken. It is much easier for me to see a little dinosaur squirrel, expert tree climber, zipping all over a tree and leaping from limb to limb. 
 
 Another problem with ground up is that you need some reason for a light bone structure before you can leave the ground. You already have this drive in a climbing animal who routinely has to impart energy to itself in the form of potential energy in climbing up high in trees. The lighter you are the less energy you are expending. 
 
 A ground animal would not benefit enough from this lightening to overcome the vulnerability associated with being a super soft target for predators. 
 
 Also, you need to impart potential energy on yourself before you can go airborne. Wouldn't climbing be the simplest way to do this? Much simpler than inefficient primitive flapping. Plus we know there were climbers. This step is already taken care of without any speculation.

 Well, not exactly. Some birds do eat insects and catch them on the fly (swallows), at night (goatsuckers and swifts). But, it's a big niche. There are enough insects to go around. Last summer I went up to Austin to see the Mexican free tailed bats exit the Congress street bridge. In late summer, about 1.5 million bats fly out from under the bridge to hunt insects. But while we were waiting for the sun to set and the bats to begin their forays, we watched the nighthawks (Chordeiles minor - Family Caprimulgidae, the Goatsuckers) soaring overhead, preying on the same insects as the bats. Of course, the birds don't use echolocation to find prey, so they aren't in the same niche as the bats. Moreover, there are many, many species of fruit bats (some 44 genera with 194 species), some known as flying foxes, that don't use echolocation and don't eat insects.
